File.Title: Connections of the Posterior Nucleus of the Amygdala
File.Authors: N.S. CANTERAS, R.B. SIMERLY, AND L.W. SWANSON

Abstract.S: The connections of a relatively homogeneous band of neurons in the caudal amygdala have been examined with anterograde and retrograde axonal tracing methods in the rat.

This region, called here the posterior nucleus of the amygdala (PA), corresponds in part to an area that has been referred to as the cortico-amygdaloid transition area, posterior part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, amygdalo-hippocampal transition area, and posteromedial basal nucleus.

Experiments with fluorogold and phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL) indicate that the major neuronal input to the PA arises in the ventral premammillary nucleus, and that substantial projections also arise in olfactory-related areas such as the medial nucleus of the amygdala, bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, and posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala, as well as in the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CAI.

Other seemingly minor inputs, including cholinergic fibers from the substantia innominata, dopaminergic fibers from the ventral tegmental area, and serotoninergic fibers from the dorsal nucleus of the raphe, were also identified.

The efferent projections of the PA as determined with the PHAL method appear to follow five major routes: 1) a relatively small group of laterally directed fibers innervates the dorsal endopiriform nucleus, and a few of these fibers reach cortical area TR and the lateral entorhinal area; 2) another small group of fibers courses medially to innervate the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CAI; 3) many fibers course ventrally to innervate the outer molecular layer of the medial part of the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala; 4) a moderate group of fibers courses rostrally to innervate primarily the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, although some fibers continue on to end less densely in rostral parts of the medial nucleus of the amygdala before leaving the amygdala through the ansa peduncularis; and 5) the major output of the PA courses through the stria terminalis.

One branch of this pathway massively innervates the principal nucleus of the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis before entering the medial hypothalamus, where it ends massively in the anteroventral periventricular and medial preoptic nuclei, ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and adjacent parts of the basal lateral hypothalamic area, and ventral premammillary nucleus.
The other branch sends fibers to the ventral lateral septal nucleus, nucleus accumbens, olfactory tubercle, and infralimbic area of the prefrontal cortex.

Projections from control injections of PHAL in distinct parts of the adjacent posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala were also described since they differ significantly from those arising in the PA.

The possible functional significance of the PA was discussed in terms of its connections and the fact that neurons here express high levels of nuclear receptors for gonadal and adrenal steroid (particularly mineralmrticoid) hormones.
Potential roles in the expression of behaviors related to salt appetite, reproduction, and aggression are particularly obvious.

Introduction.S: While it is widely recognized that the amygdala and hippocampus lie adjacent to one another in ventromedial parts Of the temporal lobe, the region surrounding the junction between them has never been subjected to detailed architectonic O r connectional analysis.

Broadly speaking, this junctional region lies on either side of the angular bundle, and consists of the so-called temporal (or ventral) pole of the hippocampal formation on the one hand, and the caudal pole of the amygdala on the other.

Crosby and Humphrey ( 44) were apparently the first to call particular attention to a relatively small band of neurons just deep to the angular bundle in the caudalmost part of the amygdala of the shrew, and named it the corticoamygdaloid transition area.
Several years later, Brodal( 47) pointed in the rat to a similar area, which he regarded as the posterior part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala.

More than 20 years later, Yu ( 69) introduced the term amygdalohippocampal transition area for what appears to be essentially the same structure in the rat, and Scalia and Winans ( 75) subsequently proposed yet another interpretation, referring to this general region in the rat, rabbit, and opossum as the posteromedial basal (or B3 ) nucleus of the amygdala.

The fact that the same general area has been regarded in the recent literature as a transitional area, as a part of the medial nucleus, or as a part of the basal nucleus, reflects a lack of knowledge about the fundamental relationship of this area to the rest of the amygdala, and in fact to the rest of the temporal lobe as a whole.

While the term amygdalohippocampal transition area is perhaps the most widely used at the moment, there seems general agreement that is not necessarily appropriate (e.g., Krettek and Price, 78b; DeOlmos et al., 85).

To shed new light on this problem, we have examined the afferent and efferent connections, as well as the cellular architecture, of this region in some detail (present report), and have compared these results with a reexamination of the output of the ventral subiculum, the most extensive component of adjacent parts of the ventral hippocampal formation (Canteras and Swanson, '92).

In addition, since the limits between this zone and the surrounding posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala (COAp) are little understood, in the present study we also reexamine the cytoarchitectonic organization of the COAp and provide a brief account of the outputs of this nucleus.

For reasons that will become apparent, we suggest that the region under consideration may be regarded as a distinct component of the deep amygdalar nuclei, and as such propose that the name posterior nucleus of the amygdala (PA) is perhaps more appropriate.
A preliminary account of this work has been presented elsewhere (Canteras et al., '89).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Adult male albino rats (275-330 g body weight) Sprague-Dawley strain were used in all experiments.
Cytoarchitecture

The cytoarchitecture of the PA and of surrounding parts of the temporal region was examined in an adjacent series of thionin-stained frozen sections prepared for each pathway tracing experiment (see below), as well as in a celloidinembedded brain from which 40-km-thick serial frontal sections had been cut, and stained with thionin (Ju and Swanson, '89; Swanson, '92).
Retrograde tracing experiments

Animals were anesthetized with tribromoethanol (0.25 gikg body weight, dissolved in 90: 10 salineiethanol, viv), and unilateral iontophoretic deposits of a 2% solution of fluorogold (Fluorochrome, Inc.; see Schmued and Fallon, '86) in 0.9% saline were placed stereotaxically into the region of the PA (five rats), the medial nucleus of the amygdala (one rat), or ventral parts of the hippocampal formation (one rat).

Deposits were made over 15 minutes through a glass micropipette (tip diameter 25 pm), using a constant-current device (Midgard Electronics, model CS3) set to deliver +5 )*A, with 7-second pulse and interpulse durations.

After a survival time of 1 week, the animals were anesthetized deeply with tribromoethanol and perfused transcardially with 100 ml of 0.15 M NaC1, followed immediately by 400 ml of 4.0% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brains were then removed and allowed to postfix overnight in the perfusate with 10% sucrose added.

Three series of 30-km-thick sections were cut on a sliding microtome in the frontal plane and collected at the following frequencies: one-in-ten through the olfactory bulbs and forebrain rostral to the vascular organ of the lamina terminalis; one-in-four through the hypothalamus and rostra1 half of the midbrain; and one-in-ten through the caudal midbrain and hindbrain.
In one series the sections were mounted onto gelatin-coated slides, and coverslipped with a buffered glycerol mountant (pH 8.5; Hartman, 73).
These slides were kept frozen in the dark at -20°C until observation.
An adjacent series was always stained with thionin to serve as a cytoarchitectonic reference series for the distribution of retrograde labeling.

A Leitz Dialux 20 microscope equipped with epifluorescence was used for observation and photography of fluorescent material, and the fluorogold was visualized with Leitz filter system A (which provides wide-band W excitation wavelengths).
For illustration purposes, the location of labeled cells was transferred onto a series of standard drawings of the rat brain (adapted from Swanson, 92).
Anterograde tracing experiments
Ten animals received an injection of Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL; Vector Laboratories) into the region of the PA.

Each animal was anesthetized with tribromoethanol, and a single iontophoretic injection of a 2.5% solution of PHAL in 0.1 M sodium phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) (Gerfen and Sawchenko, 84) was made over a 15-20 minute period through a stereotaxically positioned glass micropipette (tip diameter 10 km) by applying a +5 FA current, pulsed at 7-second intervals, that was provided by a constant-current source (Midgard Electronics, model CS3).

In addition, six animals received a PHAL deposit in the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala, and several control injections were also made into various areas that contained retrogradely labeled cells in the animals that had received fluorogold deposits in the PA.

After a survival period of 14-18 days, the animals were anesthetized deeply with tribromoethanol, and perfused transcardially with 400 ml of ice-cold 4.0% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M sodium borate buffer at pH 9.5; following a brief saline rinse, the brains were removed and postfixed overnight at 4°C in the same fixative containing 10% sucrose.
The brains were then frozen, and serial sections were collected in the same way as described for the retrograde tracing experiments.
Additional sections were collected through the injection site and quick-stained as described in detail elsewhere (see Simerly and Swanson, 88) to verify the location and size of the PHAL. deposit.
One complete series of sections was processed for immunohistochemistry with an anti-PHAL serum raised in rabbits (Dako Laboratories), at a dilution of 1:1,000.

For this series, the primary antiserum was localized by using a variation of the avidinbiotin complex system (ABC; Hsu and Raine, 81; Hsu et al., 81) described in detail by Gerfen and Sawchenko ( 84).

In brief, the sections were incubated for 45 minutes at room temperature in a solution of biotinylated goat anti-rabbit IgG (Vector Labs), and then were placed in the mixed avidin-biotin-HRP complex solution for the same period of time.

The Vectastain Elite ABC Kit was used and the working solution of avidin-biotin-HRP complex was prepared by adding 90 p1 of reagent A + 90 111 of reagent B to 10 ml of 0.02 M potassium phosphate-buffered saline at pH 7.4.

The sections were recycled through the biotinylated antibody and the avidin-biotin-HRP complex, and then processed for peroxidase histochemistry by using a 0.05% solution of diaminobenzidine (Polysciences, Inc.).

The sections were mounted on gelatin-coated slides, and the reaction product was intensified by placing the slides in a 0.005% aqueous solution of osmium tetroxide for 30 minutes followed by 15 minutes in a 0.05% aqueous solution of thiocarbohydrazide (EM Sciences), and then placed in the osmium solution for an additional 30 minutes.
Slides were then dehydrated and coverslipped with DPX.
An adjacent series was always stained with thionin to serve as a reference series.

Sections were examined with a Leitz Laborlux D microscope, and PHAL-labeled cells in the injection sites as well as the distribution of anterogradely labeled axons were plotted with the aid of a camera lucida on maps prepared from the adjacent Nissl-stained series.

For illustration purposes, and to facilitate comparison between different experiments, the distribution pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers in each experiment was transposed onto a series of standard drawings of the rat brain (see above).

Results.S: RESULTS
Cytoarchitectonic considerations
Before describing the results of our experimental work it is necessary to consider in some detail the scheme we have adopted for subdividing the caudal amygdala in the rat.

The brief historical summary in the Introduction indicated that the boundaries of what is referred to here as the PA have not been defined precisely or consistently by earlier workers, and the same general problem (including differences in nomenclature) necessarily applies to surrounding areas as well.
The following account is based on cytoarchitectonic as well as connectional criteria, and our reasons for adopting it are outlined more fully in the Discussion.
Unfortunately, no useful chemoarchitectonic guides for defining the boundaries of the PA and adjacent regions have emerged from the literature or from our own unpublished observations.
The cellular architecture and our subdivision of the caudal amygdala are illustrated in Figures 1 and 2, respectively.
Posterior nucleus of the amygdala (PA).
The PA first appears at caudal levels of the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala (MEApd) (Figs.
IA, 2A) as a distinct, thin, plate-like group of cells contiguous with deeper parts of layer 111 of the posterolateral part of the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala (COApl).
It extends posteriorly throughout most of the length of the COAp, curving along with the pyramidal layer of the overlying ventral subiculum (Figs. lD, 2D).
It is separated from the MEApd by a band of fibers related to intraamygdalar parts of the stria terminalis that continues to shield the nucleus dorsally and caudally.
The PA can be distinguished easily from the pyramidal layer of the ventral subiculum, although limits between the PA and deeper parts of the COApl are not nearly as obvious.

Careful examination of the cellular organization of the PA reveals that the region is quite homogeneous, consisting mainly of large, multipolar, deeply stained neurons that are arranged in very tightly packed clusters.

Taking into account this cytoarchitectonic feature, the border between the PA and deeper parts of the COApl can be traced rather accurately since neurons within the latter are more loosely arranged, and are stained slightly less intensely.
This account of the boundaries of the PA is supported by the results of PHAL experiments described below.

The PA corresponds approximately to what has been described as the amygdalo-hippocampal transition area, although as delineated by most authors, the latter also includes at least part of the deeper regions of the COApl (Yu, '69; Krettek and Price, '78b; Turner and Zimmer, '84; De Olmos et al., '85).
In this sense, the PA as defined here is more similar to the recent description of the amygdalohippocampal transition area by Price and his colleagues ('87).
Posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala (COAp).

The COAp can be divided into a lateral (COApl) and a medial (COApm) part, The COApm lies in the caudal third of the amygdala, ventral to the PA, and is innervated by the accessory olfactory tract (Scalia and Winans, '75).
In frontal sections it appears rostrally as a densely packed mass of cells that becomes more loosely arranged caudally.

In contrast to the COApl, the COApm has a poorly defined trilaminar structure, consisting of a molecular layer, a very thin superficial cell layer, and a deep layer, where the cells appear to be less densely packed when compared to the deep layer of the COApl, a feature that allows one to delineate more or less a border between them.
The COApm as described here corresponds approximately to that of De Olmos et al. ('85) and most of the posterior cortical nucleus of Yu ('69), Krettek and Price ('78b), and Price et al. ('87).

The COApl extends in the rostrocaudal dimension from the caudolateral border of the anterior cortical nucleus to the rostral two-thirds of the COApm, and is innervated by the lateral (main) olfactory tract (Scalia and Winans, '75).

It has a fairly well-defined trilaminar structure, with a molecular layer; a superficial cell layer made up of very chromatophilic, tightly packed pyramidal neurons; and a deep layer, presenting darkly stained, large cells that tend to arch over the deep layer of the COApm and merge with ventrolateral regions of the PA, part of which has been regarded as the superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus (Price et al., '87).

Proceeding caudally through the COApl, there is a gradual decrease in the cell density of this deep layer, especially near the border with the superficial cell layer (Fig. lD), making it more difficult to distinguish from the COApm at this level.

Embedded within rostral parts of COApl layer I1 is a massive bundle of fibers that surrounds an oval aggregate of what may be small neurons (Fig. lA), called by De Olmos et al. ('85) a small-celled part of the COApl.
Our experimental observations indicate that many of these fibers arise from the COApm and course rostrally to join the body of the stria terminalis (see Fig. 8M).
The COApl of De Olmos et al. ('85) corresponds largely to the periamygdaloid cortex of Krettek and Price ('78b).

However, it is important to point out that Krettek and Price ('78b) also included in the COApl a regon that we have recognized here as the piriform-amygdaloid area, which appears to be a distinct structure based on its cytoarchitecture and connections.
Piriform-amygdaloid area (PA4).
The PAA is a relatively well-defined, three-layered structure that lies medial to the piriform area and lateral to rostral parts of the COApl.
It extends only a short distance rostrocaudally and the more loosely arranged cells in its deep layer readily distinguish it from both the COApl and the piriform area.

Crosby and Humphrey ('41) described, in the human brain, a region interposed between the COA and the cortex of the piriform lobe, and named it the cortico-amygdaloid transitional area (hence our more specific piriform-amygdaloid area).
Brodal ('47) labeled a similar region in the rat "Y," which also includes part of the COApl as defined here.
Posterior part of the basomedial nucleus of the amgygdala (BMAp).
The BMAp is a group of neurons that first appears deep to the rostralmost tip of the COApl, and continues almost to the caudal end of the amygdala, where it abuts deeper regions of the COApl.
It lies between the basolateral nucleus dorsolaterally, and the PAiCOApl ventromedially.
The BMAp consists predominantly of smallto medium-sized neurons that become rather densely packed medially at midrostrocaudal levels.
In agreement with the earlier description of De Olmos et al. ( 851, we have also recognized an anterior part of the basomedial nucleus (BMAa), which is a distinct group of cells deep to the COAa.
The basomedial nucleus of Krettek and Price ( 78b) corresponds to our BMAp, which has also been referred to as the accessory basal nucleus by Price et al. ( 87).
The BMAp of the present account corresponds approximately to the basal nucleus described by Gurdjian ( 28), and to the basomedial nucleus delineated by Brodal 47).
Area TR (TR).
Area TR appears rostrally as a narrow region interposed between the caudal end of the piriform area laterally, and the posterior part of the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala medially.

It becomes much larger caudally, where it intercalates between the lateral entorhinal area and the caudal pole of the amygdala, which is replaced caudally by the ventral zone of the medial entorhinal area.
Area TR has a very distinctive structure, with a well-developed molecular layer, and a cellular layer that is rather indistinctly divided into superficial and deep layers.

This region was first described and named by Haug ( 76), who listed it as the area interposed between area entorhinalis caudally, and the piriform cortex and the posterior pole of the amygdala rostrally.
Area TR also corresponds more or less to the amygdalopiriform transition area described by De Olmos et al. ( 85), although it occupies a mostly postpiriform location.
Neuronal inputs to the PA

TTE.S: The distribution of neurons that project to or through the region of the PA was examined using fluorogold as a retrograde tracer.
In five experiments the deposit of tracer was centered in the PA.
Three of the injection sites appeared to be confined almost entirely to the PA, with two centered in its rostral half and one centered more caudally.
In one other experiment there was some additional involvement of the MEApd, and in yet another there was additional involvement of adjacent parts of the ventral hippocampai formation.
In addition, we obtained two relevant control injections, each with a deposit centered in one of the latter two regions.
The appearance and location of a representative fluorogold injection site in the PA is shown in Figure 3.
Each injection site consisted of a dense dye deposit in the center, a surrounding zone of intensely labeled cells, and an outer zone with faintly labeled cells.
Based on our control deposits, the concentration of tracer in the outer zone is not sufficient to label effectively afferent pathways to the caudal amygdala.
The distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons following the injection shown in Figure 3 is illustrated schematically in Figure 4.
The results of this experiment are described in detail since the injection site is virtually confined to the PA, and at the same time involves most of the nucleus.
Furthermore, the pattern of retrograde labeling in this experiment was representative of that seen in each of the others with deposits centered in the PA.
For most of the structures that contained retrogradely labeled cells we were able to confirm a projection to the PA with control experiments using PHAL as an anterograde tracer.
The following is a summary of regions that appear to send fibers to the region of the PA.
Telencephalon.
Retrogradely labeled neurons were found in the septal region, amygdala, and hippocampal formation; no retrogradely labeled cells were found in the isocortex.
In the septal region, a few labeled neurons were found in the lateral septal nucleus, particularly in its ventral part (Fig. 4A) (see Swanson and Cowan, 79 for nomenclature).
A PHAL injection centered in this region labeled a small number of fibers with terminal boutons scattered throughout the PA.

The principal (encapsulated) nucleus (BSTpr) of the BST contained several faintly labeled cells (Fig. 4B-D), although both the number of cells and the intensity of labeling were considerably increased if the deposit of fluorogold involved the MEApd.

A very few labeled neurons were also consistently found in other nuclei of the BST, including the anterodorsal area, dorsomedial nucleus, interfascicular nucleus, and transverse nucleus (Fig. 4A-D) (see Ju and Swanson, '89 for parcellation).

In one experiment with a large PHAL deposit virtually confined to the BSTpr, many labeled fibers coursed through the stria terminalis and formed a dense terminal field in the MEApd, whereas only a very few fibers continued caudally to provide a small numbers of terminal boutons in the PA.

Several retrogradely labeled neurons, which very often displayed intense labeling, were found in lateral parts of the substantia innominata, in the anterior amygdaloid area (AAA), and in rostral parts of the medial division of the central nucleus of the amygdala (Fig. 4B-F).

This was found consistently in all experiments with a fluorogold deposit involving the PA, and the intensity and extent of retrograde labeling did not appear to be influenced by the involvement of surrounding regions.
Despite the fact that these labeled cells were located in different areas, their morphology was very similar; most were medium-sized stellate or fusiform neurons.
The medial nucleus of the amygdala contained several retrogradely labeled cells, which were more frequent in the deepest sublayer of the posterodorsal part (MEApd) (Fig. 4G,H).

In several experiments with PHAL injections in rostral parts of the MEA we observed (throughout the entire rostrocaudal extent of the PA) a few labeled fibers and terminal boutons in the white matter just dorsal to the PA, as well as a dense plexus of labeled fibers just ventral to the nucleus in the COA, at caudal levels this plexus also extended into the PA.
In contrast, experiments with a PHAL deposit involving the MEApd labeled fibers that were located mainly within the rostral third of the PA.
Ventral to the rostral end of the MEA we consistently found retrogradely labeled cells in the bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract (BA) (Fig. 4F).
The number of labeled cells (and their intensity) in this nucleus increased considerably when the fluorogold deposit involved the MEA.
In one experiment, a PHAL deposit involved the BA, and we observed a moderate number of anterogradely labeled axons and terminal boutons in rostral parts of the PA.

Lateral to the PA we found several retrogradely labeled cells in the deep layer of the COApl (Fig. 4H-K); this labeling extended caudally to the level where the PA comes to lie adjacent to the ventral subiculum.
This group of labeled neurons was found in all experiments with a fluorogold deposit centered in the PA, but not in the experiment with a retrograde tracer deposit confined to the MEApd.

Experiments with a PHAL injection centered in the COAp labeled a sparse to moderate plexus of fibers in the PA, providing the injection site involved to some extent deeper parts of layer 111 of the COApl (see Fig. 7L).

Finally, as far as the amygdala is concerned, a few very faintly labeled cells were observed near the boundary between the lateral nucleus and the posterior part of the basolateral nucleus (Fig. 4H-J).
However, they were more numerous and more intensely labeled in those experiments to involve the in which the deposit of fluorogold spread hippocampal formation.
In the hippocampal formation, the pyramidal layer of both the ventral subiculum and ventral parts of field CAI contained a large number of retrogradely labeled cells (Fig. 4K,L).

With PHAL injections centered in these parts of the hippocampal formation, a moderate number of anterogradely labeled fibers and terminal boutons were observed in the PA (see Canteras and Swanson, '92).
A few retrogradely labeled cells were also found in the ventral zone of the medial entorhinal area, near its border with the ventral subiculum (Fig. 4L).
Thalamus.
In each experiment with a fluorogold deposit restricted to the PA, a very few retrogradely labeled cells were found in the paraventricular nucleus (Fig. 4EG).
Correspondingly, a PHAL injection involving this nucleus labeled a very small contingent of fibers in the PA.

Several very faintly labeled neurons were also found throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus (Fig. 4K,L) (see Faull and Mehler, '85 for parcellation).
Perhaps it is significant that retrograde labeling in the subparafascicular nucleus was markedly increased in experiments with fluorogold deposits involving the MEA.
Hypothalamus.

By far the greatest density of retrogradely labeled neurons in this part of the diencephalon was found in the ventral premammillary nucleus (Figs. 45, lOB), although a moderate number of labeled cells were found in the lateral hypothalamic area as well.
Other hypothalamic regions contained only a small number of labeled neurons.

Within the preoptic region, a very few retrogradely labeled cells were found in the preoptic periventricular nucleus, in the medial preoptic area, and in the medial preoptic nucleus (MPN) (Fig. 4B-D).
These findings are in agreement with a previous study on the efferent projections of the MPN that reported only a few labeled fibers ending within the region of the PA (Simerly and Swanson, '88).

Scattered retrogradely labeled neurons were found consistently in a region of the lateral hypothalamic area just dorsal to the optic tract that was coextensive with the anterior hypothalamic region and the rostral half of the tuberal region (Fig. 4D-G).

In experiments with a fluorogold deposit confined to the MEA or to ventral parts of the hippocampal formation, this retrograde labeling was barely detectable, i.e., it was clear only in those cases in which the injection site involved the PA.
At tuberal levels of the hypothalamus, the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus reliably contained a few labeled neurons (Fig. 4G,H).
Occasionally, retrograde labeling was also observed in the dorsomedial part of this nucleus, and in the dorsomedial nucleus of the hypothalamus as well.
In experiments with PHAL injections centered in the ventromedial nucleus, only a very few anterogradely labeled fibers were detected within the PA.
Immediately caudal to the ventromedial nucleus, the ventral premammillary nucleus contained a massive number of retrogradely labeled neurons (Figs. 45, 10B).

PHAL injections centered in this nucleus anterogradely label many fibers that course through the stria terminalis to end preferentially in the PA, which contains a dense terminal field throughout (see Canteras et al., '92).

Dorsal to the ventral premammillary nucleus afew labeled neurons were consistently found in the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, and occasionally a very few labeled cells were also found in the posterior periventricular nucleus, premammillary nucleus (Fig. 414).
At the mammillary level, a few retrogradely labeled neurons were consistently found in the lateral part of the supramammillary nucleus (Fig. 4K).

The retrograde labeling in this nucleus increased whenever the fluorogold deposit spread to involve the hippocampal formation, although it was consistently found in experiments with injection sites that appeared to be confined entirely to the PA.
Midbrain.

Caudal to the diencephalon, a small number of retrogradely labeled neurons were found in the periaqueductal gray (Fig. 4K), the dorsal nucleus of the raphe (not illustrated), and the ventral tegmental area (Fig. 4K,L).

Results.S: It should be noted that retrograde labeling of all regions was essentially ipsilateral, although a few retrogradely labeled neurons were found in the contralateral ventral premammillary and subparafascicular nuclei.
Neuronal outputs from the PA
Injection sites.
The parameters used to produce iontophoretic injections of PHAL resulted in very discrete injections sites, usually with hundreds of clearly labeled cell bodies.
In nine experiments the PHAL injection labeled many neurons within the PA, and of these, six injection sites were confined almost entirely to this nucleus.

The rostral end of the PA (before the nucleus adjoins the ventral subiculum) contained the majority of PHAL-labeled neurons in three of these experiments, whereas in the other three, labeled cells were found more caudally.

The location of the injection sites of three representative experiments iAHZ-35, AHZ-18, and AHZ-42) involving different rostrocaudal levels of the PA is indicated in the parcellation map of the caudal amygdala illustrated in Figure 2.
The appearance of the PHAL injection site in experiment AHZ-42 is illustrated in Figure 5.
Five control injections were placed in different regions of the posterior cortical nucleus and one in the piriformamygdaloid area.
The location of the injection site in each of these experiments is also shown in Figure 2.
The injection in experiment AHZ-2 labeled many superficial neurons in the COApm, as well as a small number of neurons in layer 111 of the COApl (Fig. 2B).
The injection in experiment POCL-4 labeled neurons confined entirely to layer 11, and superficial parts of layer 111, of the COApl (Fig. 2B).
A further experiment (POCL-3) labeled neurons primarily in the piriform-amygdaloid area, although several cells were also labeled in layer 11 of the COApl (Fig. 2A).
Several neurons in deep parts of the COApl bordering the PA, in addition to a few cells within the PA itself, were labeled in experiments POCL-2, PCO-2, and AHZ-15.

In contrast to experiment POCL-2, which appears to label specifically only the deepest part of the COApl (Fig. 2C), experiments PCO-2 and AHZ-15 also involve substantial parts of the COApm (Fig. 2B,D).
Efferents of the PA.

TTE.S: No consistent differences in either the pattern or density of labeled projections were observed in the six experiments with PHAL injection sites confined almost entirely to the PA.
The following description is based primarily on experiment AHZ-42, and is illustrated schematically (and in detail) in Figure 6.

It is convenient for descriptive purposes to divide anterogradely labeled axons from the PA into five pathways: 1) a lateral pathway, 2) a medial pathway, 3) a ventral pathway, 4) a rostral pathway, and 5) a pathway that courses through the stria terminalis.
Lateral pathway.

A small number of labeled fibers course laterally from the PA, through deep parts of the COAp and caudal parts of the basomedial and basolateral nuclei (Fig. 6M,N), where they issue few terminal boutons, to end in the dorsal part of the endopiriform nucleus.
In addition, a few axons continue caudally and seem to provide a very sparse innervation to deeper parts of area TR and the lateral entorhinal area (Fig. 60,P).
Virtually the entire rostrocaudal extent of the dorsal endopiriform nucleus contains labeled axons, which are much more numerous caudally (Fig. 6B-N).
Interestingly, these fibers tend to remain strictly within the borders of the nucleus, and are poorly branched.
Medial pathway.

At caudal levels of the PA a small number of labeled fibers course medially toward the hippocampal formation where they innervate the ventral subiculum and adjacent, ventral parts of field CAI (Fig. 6N-PI.

These labeled axons tend to remain in the stratum lacunosum-moleculare and the stratum radiatum, although (especially in field CAI) a few of them actually course through the pyramidal layer (Fig. 6P).
The hippocampal formation also receives very few fibers that course dorsally from the PA to reach the pyramidal layer of field CAI (Fig. 60).
Ventral pathway.

Many labeled fibers course ventrally from the injection site to provide a very dense terminal field that is restricted to a narrow band in the medialmost region of the molecular layer of the COApm (Fig. 6M-0).

This terminal field can be identified in Figure 5, ventral to the PHAL deposit, and it is worth noting here that the density of terminal boutons in this field seems to be much higher in the outer part of the molecular layer.
Some labeled fibers in this ventral pathway continue rostrally through adjacent parts of the MEApd and enter the stria terminalis (Fig. 6L).
Rostra1 pathway.
The MEA is the main intraamygdaloid target of projections from the PA.

Labeled fibers coursing rostrally from an injection site in the PA form in the posterodorsal part of this nucleus an impressive terminal field, which is particularly dense within the deepest zone of the cell layer (Fig. 6K,L).

Proceeding rostrally, the number of labeled axons in the MEA decreases gradually and they are located especially in the anterodorsal part of the nucleus, although a few labeled fibers are also found in the immediate vicinity of the MEA, as well as in the central nucleus of the amygdala (Fig. 6H-J).
At rostral levels of the amygdala, some labeled fibers enter the substantia innominata and course toward caudal parts of the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (BST) (Fig. 6G-J).
Only scattered terminal boutons were found along the fibers that course through the substantia innominata.
Stria terminalis.

The majority of labeled fibers from the PA course through the stria terminalis to end in a number of telencephalic and diencephalic sites, including the septa1 region, nucleus accumbens, infralimbic area of the prefrontal cortex, and several nuclei in the hypothalamus.
Many axons in this pathway course through the posterior division of the BST and provide a dense innervation to its principal (encapsulated) nucleus before entering the hypothalamus (Figs. 6F,G, 9C).
A smaller number of labeled fibers appear to innervate the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas of the BST, whereas only a few seem to reach the anterolateral area (Fig. 6D-F).

Labeled fibers from the stria terminalis also continue rostrally, coursing through the dorsal border of the anterodorsal area of the BST (Fig. 6D,E), and provide a significant input to other parts of the septal region, as well as other parts of the telencephalon.

Furthermore, just rostral to the anterior commissure, some of the labeled axons in this pathway take a ventral course, where they form a bundle that proceeds caudally to end in several hypothalamic nuclei (Fig. 6D).

A very dense terminal field was found in the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus, and it was unusually prominent at levels where this nucleus borders the anterodorsal area of the BST (Fig. 6D,E).
Rostrally, the labeled fibers run near the ependymal wall of the lateral ventricle, and some of them assume a ventral course toward the nucleus accumbens and the olfactory tubercle (Fig. 6B,C).

Labeled terminal boutons were strikingly more dense in caudalmost parts of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 6 0 , with only scattered labeled axons in more rostral parts of the nucleus, primarily near its border with the lateral septal nucleus (Fig. 6B).
A very small number of fibers associated with this pathway were also found to end in medial parts of the olfactory tubercle (Fig. 6B,C).
The rostralmost target of this pathway seems to be the infralimbic area, which contains a small number of labeled fibers (Fig. 6A).

Labeled axons from the stria terminalis appear to follow three distinct routes to the hypothalamus: 1) some fibers course through the posterior division of the BST to enter the hypothalamus at caudal levels of the medial preoptic nucleus; 2) other fibers course rostrally through the dorsal border of the anterolateral area of the BST and, just rostral to the anterior commissure, continue ventrocaudally toward the hypothalamus; and 3) a very small contingent of fibers skirts over the descending column of the fornix to enter the hypothalamus through the medial corticohypothalamic tract.

Together these fibers innervate several hypothalamic nuclei, particularly in the medial zone, although it does not seem possible in our PHAL material to determine the ultimate destination of fibers in each of the three pathways just mentioned since there is extensive intermixing of fibers from the three within the hypothalamus.

In the preoptic region, the anteroventral periventricular and medial preoptic nuclei contain a truly impressive number of labeled fibers and terminal boutons from the stria terminalis (Figs. 6D-G, 9A-C), in sharp contrast to what was seen in all of the experiments with injection sites centered in the COAp (see below).
Within the medial preoptic nucleus, the density of labeled axons tended to be somewhat greater in the medial part, and somewhat less in the central part (Figs. 6F, 9B).
Several labeled fibers with terminal boutons were also found in the posterodorsal preoptic nucleus (Fig. 6F).

From the preoptic region, a number of labeled fibers continue caudally through the anterior hypothalamic area; here their morphology resembles fibers-of-passage in the sense that varicosities are widely spaced and terminal boutons rare (Fig. 6H).

At rostral levels of the ventromedial nucleus, most of the labeled axons take a ventromedial course, running through the arcuate nucleus and adjacent ventral parts of the lateral hypothalamic area (Fig. 61,J).

These fibers seem to provide a dense innervation to caudal levels of the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus; thus, high densities of labeled fibers are found within this subdivision, within the ventrolateral part of the relatively cell-free zone that surrounds the nucleus, and within adjacent parts of the lateral hypothalamic area (Figs. 6K,L, 9D).
In contrast, labeled fibers were rarely found within the dorsomedial part of the ventromedial nucleus or within the dorsomedial nucleus.
Labeled axons coursing through the arcuate nucleus display very few terminal boutons and varicosities; because of this morphology, most of them are likely to be fibers-of-passage.

Many labeled fibers continue caudally to form an impressively dense terminal field in the ventral premammillary nucleus, which seems to be the caudalmost region densely innervated by the PA (Figs. 6M,N, 10A).

However, some labeled axons from this pathway can be seen to run ventral to the mammillary body and appear to end in the fiber capsule around caudal aspects of the cellular part of the medial mammillary nucleus (Fig. 6P).

A very few labeled fibers and boutons were also found in the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, the posterior periventricular nucleus, the tuberomammillary nucleus, and rostral parts of the periaqueductal gray (Fig. 6M-0).

It should also be noted that, at rostral levels of the anterior hypothalamic area, a few fibers take a dorsal course toward the thalamus, where they provide a relatively sparse innervation to rostral zones of the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus (Fig. 61-L).
In addition, a very few labeled fibers and boutons were also found in the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus, as well as in the paratenial nucleus.

Finally, it is important to point out that projections from the PA are by and large ipsilateral, although a very small number of axons cross the midline in the anterior commissure, the supraoptic commissures, and the supramammillary decussation.

Only in those regions with a very dense ipsilateral innervation, such as the lateral septal nucleus, the BST, the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, the medial preoptic nucleus, the ventromedial nucleus and adjacent lateral hypothalamic area, and the ventral premammillary nucleus, were occasional labeled fibers observed on the contralateral side.

Results.S: Injections in the COApl immediately aGacent to the PA.

The distribution of labeled axons from neurons in the COApl that lie adjacent to the PA appears to be distinct from the pattern of projections from both the PA and more superficially located neurons in the COApl or COApm.

In three experiments (POCL-2, PCO-2, and AHZ-151, the injection labeled many neurons in the deepest parts of the COApl just lateral to the PA, although a small number of cells within the PA itself were also labeled (see Fig. 2).

TTE.S: However, only in experiment POCL-2 (Fig. 2C) did the injection site appear to be virtually confined to the deepest parts of the COApl; in the other two experiments (PCO-2 and AHZ-15) there was also substantial involvement of the adjacent COApm (Fig. 2B,D).

To compare the pattern of projections from the PA with that from the deepest neurons in the adjacent COApl, we shall therefore use as a prototype experiment POCL-2, which is illustrated schematically in Figure 7, and refer to the others where relevant.
Labeled axons in experiment POCL-2 appear to follow four major routes that may be divided (at least for descriptive purposes) into lateral, and the stria terminalis.

Fibers that course laterally from the injection site take either a dorsal route through caudal parts of the basomedial and basolateral nuclei, and ventral regions of the lateral nucleus of the amygdala, or pass ventrally toward superficial layers of the COApl (Fig. 7K,L).

Labeled axons coursing through this dorsal route issue a small number of terminal boutons, and ultimately appear to provide a sparse innervation to the claustrum, dorsal endopiriform nucleus, and deeper layers of the piriform, perirhinal, agranular insular, and entorhinal areas (Fig. 7B-N).

In contrast, labeled axons coursing through the ventral component of this route form a sparse terminal field in the molecular layer of area TR (Fig. 7M,N), and a very few of them continue caudally to the lateral entorhinal area, where a small number of labeled terminal boutons were found.
Medial to the injection site, labeled fibers course through the PA and nearby parts of the COAp (Fig. 7L), both of which contain labeled terminal boutons and thus appear to be innervated.

More caudally, the labeled axons enter the hippocampal formation, where they end in the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CAI, in a fashion reminiscent of that described for the PA, although in the case of the COApl much more densely (Fig. 7M,N).
Compared to what has just been described for the PA, more fibers also seem to course rostral to the injection site, though the amygdala.
Thus, in experiment POCL-2 (and in experiments PCO-2 and AHZ-15) inputs to the MEApd were far less dense than in experiments with injections in the PA (Fig. 7K).

However, in all three experiments involving the COAp, a denser plexus of labeled fibers was found in and around the MEAad, as well as in the central nucleus of the amygdala, where labeled fibers were particularly obvious in the capsular subdivision (Fig. 7H-K).

At rostral levels of the amygdala, labeled axons enter the substantia innominata, coursing toward caudal parts of the BST (Fig. 7GJ), and appear to be more numerous in this experiment than in any of those centered in the PA.

In addition, a very few fibers were seen continuing rostral to the amygdala, where they seem to provide a very sparse input to the fundus of the striatum and to medial parts of the olfactory tubercle (Fig. 7C-GI.
As with the PA, the major route followed by labeled fibers from neurons located in deeper parts of layer I11 of the COApl appears to be the stria terminalis.

These axons provide inputs to the same general regions of the telencephalon and diencephalon as do those from the PA, although quite often both display characteristically different patterns of innervation within each region.
In the case of the deeper parts of layer I11 of the COApl, many labeled fibers course through the posterior division of the BST as they leave the stria terminalis to enter the hypothalamus.
In the BST, labeled axons tend to avoid the principal nucleus, and instead seem to provide a dense innervation to the interfascicular and transverse nuclei (Fig. 7G).

On the other hand, the projection to the anterior division of the BST is quite similar to that from the PA, such that labeled fibers appear to innervate the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas, and tend to avoid the anterolateral area (Fig. 7D-F).

Some fibers in this pathway continue rostrally through the dorsal border of the anterodorsal area of the BST to end in the septal region, nucleus accumbens, and infralimbic area, while other fibers take a ventral course just rostral to the anterior commissure (Fig. 7D); these fibers continue on to targets in the hypothalamus.

In this experiment (as well as in experiments PCO-2 and AHZ-15), labeled fibers enter the septal region at the rostral pole of the BST, and innervate the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus, as well (to a lesser extent) as the intermediate and dorsal parts of the nucleus (Fig. 7B-E).

Compared to the projection from the PA, the plexus of labeled fibers in the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus is far less dense, although in all three experiments involving the deepest parts of the COApl, labeled fibers appear to be more evenly distributed throughout all parts of the lateral nucleus.
In experiment POCL-2, the patterns of projections to the nucleus accumbens and infrahbic area were very s i d a r to those described earlier for the PA (Fig. 7A-C).

In contrast to experiments with injection sites more restricted to superficial parts of the COApl and to the COApm, experiments POCL-2, PCO-2, and AHZ-15 labeled a very striking projection to the hypothalamus.

Also, in contrast to experiments with injections confined to the PA, very few axons in these experiments seem to end in the preoptic region; these few fibers were located mainly in the undifferentiated part of the medial preoptic area and in the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus (Fig. 7E-G).

Both the preand postcommissural components of labeled fibers from the stria terminalis merge at caudal levels of the medial preoptic nucleus (Fig. 7G) before continuing caudally through the anterior hypothalamic area (Fig. 7H) to end massively in medial parts of the tuberal region of the hypothalamus.

Thus, experiments POCL-2 and PCO-2 labeled a dense terminal field in ventral parts of the lateral hypothalamic area adjacent to the ventromedial nucleus, in the cell-sparse zone surrounding the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus, and in the caudal half of the ventrolateral part of this nucleus (Fig. 7J,K).

In addition, some labeled axons were found in the cell-sparse zone around the dorsomedial part of the ventromedial nucleus (Fig. 7K), although such fibers were much more obvious in experiment AHZ-15, in which the injection labeled more medially placed deep cells in the COApl than in experiments POCL-2 and PCO-2 (see Fig. 2).

Just caudal to the ventromedial nucleus, several labeled fibers were seen within the ventral premammillary nucleus (Fig. 7L), and a small group of fibers continued on ventral to the mammillary body, where they seem to end in the fiber capsule around the caudal cellular border of the medial mammillary nucleus (Fig. 7N).

The pattern of thalamic projections in these experiments was very similar to that described for the PA, with only scattered fibers that seem to end rostrally in the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus, as well as in the paraventricular and paratenial nuclei (Fig. 7H-K).

Finally, in experiment POCL-2, only a few fibers were observed on the contralateral side, in contrast to the results presented next in experiments PCO-2, AHZ-15, and others, in which the injection site labeled superficial cells in the COApl or COApm.
As discussed below, the latter experiments labeled a significant number of fibers that seem to cross mainly through the anterior commissure.
Injections in the COApm and in superficial parts of the COApl.

A similar pattern of projections was observed in experiment AHZ-2 (in which the injection site involved mainly the COApm and to a lesser extent superficial parts of the COApl, as shown in Fig. 2B), and in experiment POCL-4 (in which the injection site was restricted to layer 11 and superficial regions of layer I11 of the COApl, as shown in Fig. 2B).

However, both of these experiments labeled a pattern of projection very distinct from those just described for injection sites involving deeper parts of layer I11 of the COApl, immediately adjacent to the PA.

To illustrate this pattern, we shall discuss experiment AHZ-2 (Fig. 8) in detail, and refer when necessary to experiment POCL-4, as well as to other experiments that involved substantially the COApm (experiments PCO-2 and AHZ-15) (Fig. 2B,D).
We shall also refer to experiment POCL-3, in which the injection site was centered in the pirifom-amygdaloid area (Fig. 2A).

From the injection site in experiment AHZ-2, an impressive plexus of labeled fibers diverges immediately to fill virtually all cellular parts of the COAp, except for rostral parts of layer I1 in the COApl (Fig. 8L-0).
It is worth pointing out that the PA is virtually free of anterograde labeling (Fig. 8M-0).
At caudal levels of the COAp, labeled fibers take a lateral course and form a moderate terminal field in the molecular layer of area TR (Fig. 80,P).

Furthermore, a number of fibers pass through this area on their way to the entorhinal area, where they seem to end relatively densely in the lateral part, and to a lesser extent in superficial layers (especially layer 11) of the medial part (Fig. 80-Q).
A very few labeled fibers extended even farther into the adjacent parasubiculum (Fig. 8Q).

At the caudal pole of the COAp, a massive group of labeled fibers enters the hippocampal formation, where labeled axons and terminal boutons are found in the ventral subiculum and field CAI (Fig. 80,P).

This projection is especially dense in ventral parts of field CAI, where labeled fibers tend to be confined to the stratum lacunosum-moleculare, but occasionally enter the stratum radiatum, where they extend toward the pyramidal layer (Fig. 8P).
A similar (but somewhat more dense) projection to the entorhinal area, subiculum, and Ammon s horn was also observed in experiments POCL-4 and POCL-3.
Many labeled fibers course laterally and seem to provide distinct inputs to the endopiriform nucleus, piriform area, and dorsal and ventral agranular insular areas (Fig. 8C-N).
A smaller number of labeled axons were also found in the posterior agranular insular area, as well as in the perirhinal area (Fig. 8F-Q).
More medial parts of the piriform area received a particularly striking innervation, which included a number of labeled fibers in the deep half of the molecular layer (Fig. 8H-N).

It is worth noting that in experiment POCL-3, in which the injection site spread to involve the piriform-amygdaloid area, projections to the endopiriform nucleus and to the agranular insular areas were clearly more dense than in experiments with injections restricted to the COAp.

Rostral to the injection site, a dense bundle of labeled fibers coursing through the small-celled part of the COAp (associated with layer I1 of the posterolateral part) was particularly obvious in this experiment (Fig. 8M), and to a lesser extent in experiment POCL-4.
Many of these fibers enter the stria terminalis, while others continue through the amygdala and adjacent regions.

From the injection site, a massive contingent of fibers continues rostrally and seems to provide a heavy innervation to virtually all parts of the amygdala ventral to the central and basolateral nuclei.

The MEA contained an exceedingly dense plexus of labeled fibers and boutons, which, interestingly enough, tend to avoid the deepest sublayer in its posterodorsal subdivision (Fig. 8L,M), and the anteroventral part (Fig. 8K).

Ventral to rostral parts of the MEA, the bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract was also heavily innervated, in stark contrast to the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, which was virtually free of anterograde labeling (Fig. 81-K).

This experiment, along with experiment POCL-4, displayed similar patterns of inputs to the amygdala, in contrast to experiment POCL-3, in which the PHAL deposit also involved the piriform-amygdaloid area, and a remarkably dense plexus of labeled fibers was observed in the lateral nucleus of the amygdala.
At rostral levels of the amygdala in experiment AHZ-2, labeled fibers entered the substantia innominata, coursing toward the caudal end of the BST.

In addition, some of the rostrally directed fibers were found to provide inputs to medial parts of the olfactory tubercle, to the fundus of the striatum, and to ventral regions of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 8D-H).

A few of these fibers continue on through anteromedial parts of the nucleus accumbens, where they join a group of axons that travels through the stria terminalis and then along the medial wall of the lateral ventricle (Fig. 8D).
Together, these fibers project to the infralimbic area and the accessory olfactory bulb, as discussed below.
An impressive number of labeled fibers leave the amygdala by way of the stria terminalis (Fig. 8M).

At the level of the posterior division of the BST, fibers coursing through this pathway provide a dense input to the interfascicular and transverse nuclei, tending to avoid the principal nucleus (Fig. 81), as do fibers from deeper parts of the COApl (experiment POCL-2).

At the rostral pole of the posterior division of the BST, many labeled fibers cross through the anterior commissure (Fig. 8H), while another contingent of labeled axons continues rostrally through the dorsal edge of the anterodorsal area of the BST (Fig. 8F,G).
The projection to the anterior division of the BST appears to be much less dense than that described for the PA, and the labeled fibers are more restricted to its anterodorsal area (Fig. 8F-H).

The labeled fibers coursing through the dorsal edge of the anterolateral area appear to provide inputs to the septal region, nucleus accumbens, infralimbic area, taenia tecta, anterior olfactory nucleus and accessory olfactory bulb.
In addition, just rostral to the anterior commissure, a very small number of these fibers take a ventral route toward the hypothalamus (Fig. 8F).
The septal region is very sparsely innervated, in sharp contrast to results obtained in experiments with injections involving either the PA or the deep cells of the COApl.
Nevertheless, scattered labeled fibers were found in the septofimbrial nucleus, triangular nucleus, and lateral septal nucleus (Fig. 8D-H).
In experiments POCL-4 and POCL-3, even fewer labeled fibers were observed within the septal region.

At rostral levels of the septal region, a number of labeled fibers continue on rostrally, near the wall of the lateral ventricle, while others course ventrally to end in caudal parts of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 8D,E).
A moderately dense terminal field was found in the infralimbic area, where a particularly obvious plexus of fibers could be seen in the molecular layer (Fig. 8C).
In all experiments with an injection involving the COApm, labeled fibers were observed to end in the granule cell layer of the accessory olfactory bulb, where they form a dense plexus (Fig. 8A).

In experiment AHZ-2, as well as experiment POCL-4, only a few scattered fibers were labeled in the hypothalamus, in sharp contrast to experiments with a deposit of PHAL that also labeled deeper cells of layer I11 in the COApl, immediately adjacent to the PA.

Finally, the prominent fiber bundle seen crossing through the anterior commissure was found to provide especially dense terminal fields to the interfascicular and transverse nuclei of the BST on the other side of the brain.
In addition, some of these fibers enter the contralateral stria terminalis and eventually reach the amygdala.
Some of these labeled fibers appear to end within the MEA, as well as within the COAp, particularly in the region precisely contralateral to the injection site.
It is important to point out that in experiments PCO-2, AHZ-15, POCL-4, and POCL-3, the number of crossed fibers was very much smaller.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The major conclusion that can be drawn from the experimental results presented here is that one can identify a relatively homogeneous group of neurons deep within the caudal tip of the amygdala with characteristic neuronal inputs and outputs that are distinct from the adjacent posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala.

The major neuronal inputs to this cell group, which we have called the posterior nucleus of the amygdala, appear to arise in the medial nucleus of the amygdala, the deeper parts of the posterolateral subdivision of the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala, the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of the hippocampal field CAI, and especially the ventral premammillary nucleus, while its major neuronal projections appear to end in these same regions, as well as in the principal nucleus of the BST and a number of cell groups associated with the periventricular and medial zones of the hypothalamus.

In the following discussion, we shall consider the experimental techniques upon which these conclusions have been drawn, the relationship of these results to evidence in the earlier literature, and the possible functional implications of our work.
Neuronal inputs to the PA

To clarify the distribution of neurons that project to the PA we first used fluorogold, since it has been shown to be a very sensitive retrograde tracer that provides relatively discrete, effective injection sites (see Schmued and Fallon, '86; Pieribone and Aston-Jones, '88).

Nevertheless, it has the disadvantage that damaged and undamaged fibers passing through the region of the injection site may take up the tracer and retrogradely label cells that do not give rise to terminals in the injection site (see Dado et al., '90).
To address this problem, most of the regions that contained retrogradely labeled cells after tracer injections in the PA received an injection of the anterograde tracer PHAL, in control experiments.

To our knowledge, the only attempt to define possible inputs to the PA was reported by Ottersen ('801, who described a few retrogradely labeled neurons in the lateral hypothalamic area, substantia innominata, medial preoptic area, and medial division of the BST, in one experiment with a small horseradish peroxidase deposit that was centered in the region of the PA.

The results of our retrograde and anterograde axonal transport experiments extend considerably these previous observations, and indicate that the PA may receive inputs from several widely distributed areas in the forebrain, and also to a much lesser extent from the brainstem.

From this, it would appear that the main sources of inputs to the PA from the telencephalon are the medial nucleus of the amygdala, the bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, deeper parts of the COApl, the ventral subiculum and ventral parts of field CAI, and a group of neurons with similar morphological features distributed throughout lateral parts of the substantia innominata, the anterior amygdaloid area, and rostra1 parts of the central nucleus of the amygdala.

In the diencephalon, inputs to the PA seem to arise mainly from the ventral premammillary nucleus, which supplies by far the most dense known input to the PA, as well as from a group of cells located just dorsal to the optic tract in the lateral hypothalamic area throughout the anterior hypothalamic region and rostral parts of the tuberal region.
In the brainstem we found only a few retrogradely labeled neurons, located in the dorsal nucleus of the raphe, the ventral tegmental area, and the periaqueductal gray.
It also became apparent in our experimental material that the PA seems to receive sparse inputs from several areas that provide a very dense input to the nearby MEApd.

These regions include the principal nucleus of the BST (Ottersen, '80), the medial preoptic area (Conrad and Pfaff, '76; Ottersen, '80; Chiba and Murata, '85; Simerly and Swanson, '881, and the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus (Faull and Mehler, '85).

Based on our retrograde tracer experiments, this also seems to be the case for the posterior part of the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala and for the supramammillary nucleus, both of which are known to innervate densely the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CAI (Krettek and Price, '77b; see Swanson et al., '87), and both of which contained only a few labeled neurons whenever the fluorogold deposit was centered in the PA and did not spread to involve the hippocampal formation.

Our retrograde transport experiments did not label a projection from the basomedial nucleus of the amygdala to the PA, a pathway reported in the cat by Krettek and Price ('78b), who used the autoradiographic method.

This discrepancy would easily be explained if the injection site in the experiment described by these authors encroached slightly on deeper parts of the adjacent COApl (see below), although we cannot rule out the possibility of species differences in this projection.

In agreement with previous studies, we did not label a projection from the olfactory bulb directly to the PA, although it seems likely (see below) that the nucleus receives olfactory information relayed from the medial nucleus of the amygdala, the bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, and less directly from deep parts of the COApl, and/or the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CAI.

Using the autoradiographic method in the cat, Krettek and Price ('78b) described a projection to the region of the PA from the periamygdaloid cortex, which, according to the cytoarchitectonic parcellation scheme adopted here, corresponds to the piriform-amygdaloid area and the COApl.
Based on our retrograde and anterograde tracer experiments, the source of this projection is almost certainly neurons in the deeper regions of the COApl.

As far as we can determine, projections to the PA from the bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, the medial nucleus of the amygdala, and the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CAI have not been reported before.

It is known that both the medial nucleus and the bed nucleus receive a direct projection from the accessory olfactory bulb (Scalia and Winans, '751, and the medial nucleus is also innervated by superficial neurons in the COApl and COAa (Krettek and Price, '78b; Ottersen, '821, both of which in turn receive direct inputs from the main olfactory bulb (Price, '73; Scalia and Winans, '75).

Another site where indirect influences from the accessory and main olfactory pathways may well converge is the deeper regions of the COApl, since it is densely innervated by superficial neurons in both the posteromedial and posterolateral parts of the COA.

In addition, olfactory information may well be relayed to the PA by the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CAI, which are known to be densely innervated by several areas that receive direct inputs from either the main or the accessory olfactory bulb, including the posteromedial and posterolateral parts of the COA, the piriform-amygdaloid area, and the lateral entorhinal area (Price, '73; Scalia and Winans, '75; Krettek and Price, '77b; Witter et al., '88).

It may also be important to point out that the apparently massive projections from the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CA1 constitute a potential route for the relay of information in the hippocampal trisynaptic circuit to the PA.

The trisynaptic circuit in turn receives information, either directly or indirectly, from virtually all parts of the isocortex, and is somehow involved in the "short-term" storage of memories, as well as their transfer to isocortical regions involved in their storage for much longer periods of time (see Swanson et al., '87).

Turning now to subcortical afferents, our retrograde tracer experiments indicate that at least a few neurons in the substantia innominata project to the PA, in agreement with previous results based on the use of PHAL as an anterograde tracer (Grove, '88b).

Hellendall et al. ('86), using a monoclonal antibody against choline acetyltransferase (ChAT), found a dense plexus of presumably cholinergic fibers in the region of the amygdalo-hippocampal area, although according to the parcellation used here this plexus appears to be much more dense just lateral to the PA itself, in what we regard as the deep part of the COApl, and in medial parts of the basomedial nucleus (see Fig. 1F in Hellendall et al., '86).

It is tempting to suggest that the CUT-immunoreactive fibers in the PA might arise from the substantia innominata, which also appears to be the source of a cholinergic input to the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala (Woolf and Butcher, '82; Carlsen et al., '85).

The anterior amygdaloid area, as well as rostral parts of the medial division of the central nucleus, also contained retrogradely labeled neurons after fluorogold injections in the PA, and these cells were morphologically similar to labeled neurons in the substantia innominata.

It has been pointed out that the substantia innominata, anterior amygdaloid area, and medial division of the central nucleus share certain cytoarchitectonic (Yu, '69; De Olmos et al., '85; Price et al., '87) and connectional (Grove, '88a) features in common, although it is not known whether the cells in all three regions that project to the PA are cholinergic.

The results of our retrograde transport experiments indicate strongly that the PA receives a projection from a very specific group of neurons in the lateral hypothalamic area that is located just dorsal to the optic tract, at the level of the anterior hypothalamic region and rostral parts of the tuberal region.
The possible functional significance of this projection is entirely unknown, although considering the number of retrogradely labeled neurons, it should provide at least a moderate input to the PA.
Our results indicate that the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus sends very few axons to the PA, in agreement with previous autoradiographic studies (Saper et al., '76; Krieger et al., '79).
On the other hand, our results demonstrate that the ventral premammillary nucleus is by far the most prominent source of inputs to the PA.

It is known that the ventral premammillary nucleus contains a very high density of cells that concentrate circulating gonadal steroids (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '75; Stumpf et al., '7.51, and recently it has been shown that neurons in this nucleus express high levels of the mRNA encoding the androgen and, to a lesser extent, the estrogen receptors (Simerly et al., '90).

Furthermore, the ventral premammillary nucleus receives afferents mainly from structures related to the sexually dimorphic circuit, including the PA, the medial nucleus of the amygdala, the principal nucleus of the BST, and the medial preoptic nucleus (Krettek and Price, '78a; Kevetter and Winans, '81; Simerly and Swanson, '88; see Canteras et al., '921, which are also among the regions of the brain containing the highest density of neurons with gonadal steroid hormone receptors (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '75; Stumpf et al., '75; Simerly et al., '90).
Thus, information generated in the sexually dimorphic circuit appears to be transmitted to the PA mainly by way of the ventral premammillary nucleus.
Unfortunately, we have as yet no clue about the neurotransmitters used in this pathway from the ventral premammillary nucleus.

In agreement with the results of our retrograde tracer experiments, previous evidence based on the autoradiographic method indicates that a few neurons in the dorsal nucleus of the raphe project to the PA (Conrad et al., '74; Azmitia and Segal, '78).
The rostra1 two-thirds of the PA contains a plexus of serotoninergic fibers (Steinbusch, '81; N.S.
Canteras, R.B.
Simerly, and L.W.

Swanson, unpublished observations), and it appears likely that these fibers arise from the dorsal nucleus of the raphe, since no other serotoninergic cell group contained retrogradely labeled neurons in our experiments.
Our fluorogold results also suggest that the ventral tegmental area provides a small input to the PA, in agreement with previous autoradiographic studies (Fallon and Moore, '78; Simon et al., '79).
In addition, it has been shown by Fallon et al. ('78) with the glyoxylic acid method that there are a small number of catecholaminergic fibers in the region of the PA.

Since we found no retrograde labeling in brainstem regions that contain noradrenergic cell groups, and since dopamine-0-hydroxylase-immunoreactive fibers have not been reported in the PA (see Swanson and Hartman, '75), the evidence as a whole suggests that the ventral tegmental area sends a small number of dopaminergic fibers to the PA.
Hormonal inputs to the PA

The PA contains high levels of mRNA encoding the mineralocorticoid receptor (MR), which binds with high affinity both the naturally occurring mineralocorticoid aldosterone, and the glucocorticoids (Arriza et al., '88).

It has also been reported that many neurons concentrating gonadal steroid hormones are found in the PA (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '74), as are neurons that express high levels of mRNAs for the androgen (AR) and estrogen (ER) receptors (Simerly et al., '90).
Thus, in addition to neural inputs, the PA may be influenced significantly by circulating steroid hormones.

Furthermore, if individual neurons in this nucleus do in fact express each of these receptors, complex interactions between various steroid hormones may combine in unique ways to influence neuronal function in this region of the brain (see Ankenbauer et al., '88; Green and Chambon, '87; Arriza et al., In summary, olfactory information may be relayed to the PA by the medial nucleus of the amygdala, the bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, deeper parts of the COApl, and the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CAI.

It is also possible that the latter two regions transmit to the PA information related to activity generated in widespread areas of the isocortex as well as in the trisynaptic circuit of the hippocampus.

The PA also receives a relatively small number of cholinergic, serotoninergic, and dopaminergic fibers, which appear to arise, respectively, in the substantia innominata, the dorsal nucleus of the raphe, and the ventral tegmental area.

Nevertheless, neural influences on the PA seem to be dominated by information generated in the sexually dimorphic circuit, which is especially transmitted to the nucleus by way of the ventral premammillary nucleus.
In addition, it is important to bear in mind that neurons in the PA may be strongly influenced by circulating steroid hormones as well.
Neuronal outputs of the PA
Our results confirm and extend in many ways what was previously known about the projections of the PA, as well as the adjacent COAp (for summary see Fig. 11).
However, because the validity of our findings rests on the properties of the PHAL method, we should consider its major features before discussing our results.

As originally described by Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84), the PHAL method allows the production of very small iontophoretic injections, and the effective limits of the injection site can be determined precisely because the cells that give rise to labeled axons are themselves clearly labeled.

Another advantage of this method is that the detailed morphology of each labeled axon can be visualized with the clarity of a Golgi impregnation, and the presence of terminal boutons (including boutons-of-passage) can be established with certainty.

While it is true that the presence of morphologically defined synapses must be established at the ultrastructural level, it is also true that everywhere terminal boutons have been examined with the electron microscope, they have been shown to form synapses (see, e.g., Rockel and Jones, '73; Wouterlood and Groenewegen, '85).

The final major advantage of the method is that under the injection conditions recommended by Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84), retrograde labeling is absent or extremely rare, and labeling of fibers-of-passage has never been demonstrated unequivocally (i.e., from regions that clearly contain no dendrites that could take up the tracer and confound the interpretation of axonal uptake).

One important point to make at the outset is that our results are based on five PHAL injection sites with labeled neurons confined almost entirely to the PA, and that virtually all parts of the PA were labeled by one or another of these injections.

Nevertheless, the patterns of labeled projections in each of these five experiments were indistinguishable, suggesting that neurons throughout the PA as we have defined its borders give rise to very similar projections.

It is equally important to point out, however, that there is no evidence to indicate whether these projections arise from a single cell type or from multiple cell types that are intermixed in some uniform or reproducible way.

Finally, it is worth pointing out that neurons in immediately adjacent parts of the posterior cortical nucleus give rise to a different pattern of connections, as discussed more fully in the next section.

With this information in mind, we can now summarize the output of the PA as follows: it appears to be largely ipsilateral and, at least for descriptive purposes, to travel through five basic pathways: 1) a lateral pathway that seems to innervate mainly the dorsal endopiriform nucleus; 2) a medial pathway that projects to the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CAI; 3) a ventral pathway that seems to provide a dense input to the molecular layer of the COApm; 4) a rostra1 pathway that courses through the amygdala, and provides an input to the MEApd, before entering the ansa peduncularis; and 5) a pathway through the stria terminalis, which is by far the main route followed by axons from the PA, to several regions of the telencephalon and diencephalon.

Anterogradely labeled axons coursing laterally from PHAL deposits in the PA provide a relatively moderate input to the dorsal endopiriform nucleus, although in contrast to experiments with PHAL injections in the posterior cortical nucleus or the piriform-amygdaloid area, very few fibers were found in the adjacent piriform area, or in adjacent cortical areas near the rhinal fissure.
Projections from the COApl and piriform-amygdaloid area to cortical areas near the rhinal fissure have been reported in the rat (Luskin and Price, '83; McDonald and Jackson, '87).
Furthermore, McDonald and Jackson ('87) used HRP as a retrograde tracer to describe a projection from lateral parts of the amygdalo-hippocampal area to the perirhinal area.

The amygdalo-hippocampal area defined by these authors does not correspond exactly to our delineation of the PA, since their area also includes deeper parts of the posterolateral cortical nucleus that actually contain many more retrogradely labeled neurons than the PA itself in the experiment with an HRP deposit centered in the perirhinal area that they illustrated (see case R-123 in McDonald and Jackson, '87).
In short, their observations are in complete agreement with the results of our anterograde tracer experiments.

Our results also indicate that the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of field CAI receive a moderate input from the PA, whereas the entorhinal area seems to receive very few inputs from this nucleus.
In contrast, a significantly more dense projection to all of these components of the hippocampal formation appears to arise from the posterior cortical nucleus, as discussed below.

Projections from the periamygdaloid cortex (which according to our parcellation includes both the piriform-amygdaloid area and the COApl) to the ventral subiculum, to ventral parts of field CAI, and to the entorhinal area have been described with the autoradiographic method (Krettek and Price, '77b; Luskin and Price, '831, and our results suggest that the COApm projects heavily to these same areas as well.
Within the amygdala, the main recipients of projections from the PA are the MEApd and medialmost parts of the molecular layer of the COApm.
The latter projection is of interest because the accessory olfactory tract also ends mainly in superficial parts of the molecular layer of the COApm (Scalia and Winans, '75).
It will be important to determine whether the PA input acts presynaptically on these fibers or whether it interacts with the distal dendrites of neurons in deeper parts of the COApm.
A projection from the PA to the region of the medial nucleus of the amygdala was suggested by Ottersen ('82) on the basis of HRP retrograde tracer experiments in the rat.

According to our results, the projection from the PA to the medial nucleus is directed mainly to its posterodorsal part, in contrast to inputs from the posterior cortical nucleus, which tend to avoid the deepest sublayer of the MEApd.
