It is worth remarking here that the projection from the PA to the MEApd appears to be far stronger than the reverse PA, which has been projection from the MEApd to the discussed earlier in this paper.

Interestingly, the PA and the MEApd project to the same regions of the BST and hypothalamus, all of which are known to be related to the sexually dimorphic circuit (Simerly and Swanson, '86; Simerly et al., '89; N.S.
Canteras, R.B.
Simerly, and L.W.
Swanson, unpublished observations), as discussed below.

Like the PA, the MEApd contains many neurons that concentrate gonadal steroids (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '741, and express high levels of the mRNAs encoding the androgen and estrogen receptors (Simerly et al., '90).
In addition, the medial nucleus is larger in males and its synaptic organization is sexually dimorphic as well (see Arai, '84).
Nevertheless, the MEApd and the PA appear to be influenced differentially by areas related to the sexually dimorphic circuit.

In contrast to the PA, the MEApd receives a direct input from the accessory olfactory pathway and is densely innervated by the principal nucleus of the BST and the medial preoptic nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, '88; Simerly et al., '89).
In addition, unlike the PA, neurons within the MEApd appear to express very low levels of mRNA encoding nuclear receptors for mineralocorticoids (Arriza et al., '88).

Our experimental material demonstrates that a great majority of the fibers arising in the PA leave the amygdala through the stria terminalis, in agreement with previous suggestions based on the autoradiographic method (Krettek and Price, '78a) or on retrograde tracing combined with lesions of the stria terminalis (Maragos et al., '89).

A small number of fibers were also observed coursing through the ansa peduncularis in our material, although the number of such fibers increased considerably whenever the PHAL deposit involved the posterior cortical nucleus.

Fibers coursing through the stria terminalis from the PA provide inputs to a number of telencephalic and diencephalic regions, including the BST, lateral septal nucleus, nucleus accumbens, olfactory tubercle, infralimbic area, several hypothalamic nuclei, and certain thalamic nuclei.
The PA and the posterior cortical nucleus also give rise to very different patterns of input to the BST.

Both project mainly to the posterior division of the BST, although efferent fibers from the PA give rise to a dense terminal field within the principal nucleus, whereas the posterior cortical nucleus projects densely to the interfascicular and transverse nuclei.
Krettek and Price ('78a), using the autoradiographic method, reported that both the amygdalohippocampal area and the posterior cortical nucleus project to the medial division of the BST.
The medial division of Krettek and Price ('78a) appears to encompass both the principal nucleus and at least parts of the interfascicular and transverse nuclei of the present account (see Fig.
Id in Krettek and Price, '78a; and Fig. 7 in Ju and Swanson, '89).
It should be pointed out, however, that none of the injections reported by Krettek and Price ('78a) were restricted to the PA.

Interestingly, the PA and the principal nucleus of the BST have virtually the same pattern of projections to the hypothalamus (Simerly et al., '891, and, as noted above, both innervate densely the MEApd.

The principal nucleus also contains a high density of neurons that concentrate gonadal steroids, as well as express high levels of mRNAs encoding the androgen and estrogen receptors (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '74; Simerly et al., '90).
This nucleus is also larger in males as compared to females, in guinea pigs and rats (Hines et al., '85).

Thus, the PA together with the MEApd and the principal nucleus of the BST form an interconnected circuit within the telencephdon that can be influenced by circulating gonadal steroids, and that shares practically the same pattern of projections to the hypothalamus.

The PA supplies a particularly dense input to the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus, in contrast to the posterior cortical nucleus, which appears to provide a much sparser projection that also tends to be more dispersed through other parts of the septal region.
Evidence for a projection from the PA to the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus was adduced by Krettek and Price ('78a) in the rat with the autoradiographic method.

Interest in this projection centers around the fact that the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus is another telencephalic region densely innervated by the PA that also seems to be related to the sexual dimorphic circuit.

Thus, the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus contains many neurons that concentrate gonadal steroids, as well as express mRNAs encoding the androgen and estrogen receptors (PfdF and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '74; Simerly et al., '90); it, along with certain other parts of the lateral septal nucleus, contains a greater density of vasopressin-immunoreactive fibers in male as compared to female rats (DeVries et al., '84); it shares strong bidirectional connections with the medial preoptic nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, '86, '88); and it receives a dense projection from the ventral premammillary nucleus (Canteras et al., '92).

Turning now to the striatum, the caudalmost regions of the nucleus accumbens receive a moderate plexus of labeled fibers from the PA, in agreement with earlier suggestions based on the autoradiographic method (Krettek and Price, '78a), and on the retrograde transport of horseradish peroxidase (Phillipson and Griffiths, '85).
Ventral to the nucleus accumbens, only scattered fibers from the PA course to the olfactory tubercle.

The latter is in sharp contrast to what was observed in experiments with PHAL deposits in the postrior cortical nucleus, where labeled fibers continue rostral to the amygdala to provide a more dense input to the olfactory tubercle.
The rather sparse projection from the PA to the prefrontal cortex appears from our anterograde material to be restricted to the infralimbic area.

A projection from the PA to the medial prefrontal region in the rat was reported by McDonald ('87), who used fluorescent retrograde tracer injections that involved both the prelimbic and infralimbic areas.

According to our anterograde results, the posterior cortical nucleus projects more densely to the infralimbic area than does the PA, which agrees with our observations in an experiment with a fluorogold deposit centered in this cortical region; in this experiment the posterior cortical nucleus contained considerably more retrogradely labeled neurons than the PA (N.S.
Canteras, R.B.
Simerly, and L.W.
Swanson, unpublished observations).

The mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus, which is known to be intimately related to the prefrontal region (see Krettek and Price, '77a), also receives a very sparse projection from the PA, in agreement with previous observations based on retrograde tracer experiments (McDonald, '87).
In addition, this projection appears to be directed especially to the rostral end of the medial part of this nucleus.

Fibers from the PA provide a massive input to several nuclei within the periventricular and medial zones of the hypothalamus, including the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, the medial preoptic nucleus, the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and adjacent parts of the lateral hypothalamic area, and the ventral premammillary nucleus.

The projection to the medial preoptic nucleus has been shown with retrograde tracer methods (Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Simerly and Swanson, '86; Maragos et al., '891, and we were able to determine here that it is directed mainly to the medial part of this nucleus.

Just rostral to the MPN in the preoptic region, another dense plexus of labeled fibers from the PA was found in the anteroventral periventricular nucleus; this pathway does not seem to have been reported previously.

Injections of retrograde tracers centered in the ventromedial nucleus have been found to label cells within the region of the PA (Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Kita and Oomura, '82; Zaborsky, '82; Ono et al., '85; Fahrbach et al., '89).

According to our anterograde tracer experiments, fibers arising in the PA form a dense terminal field within the caudal half of the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and within adjacent parts of the basal lateral hypothalamic area.

This finding is at variance with the results of previous autoradiographic studies in the rat, in which a projection to the entire extent of the cell-sparse zone or shell surrounding the nucleus has been reported (Krettek and Price, '78a; Post and Mai, '80).

A reasonable explanation for this discrepancy may well be that in the experiments reported by these authors the injection site spread to include small parts of the ventral subiculum, which clearly project densely to the entire shell region surrounding the ventromedial nucleus (Krettek and Price, '78a; Canteras and Swanson, '92).
In this study we have also established the existence of a very dense projection to the ventral premammillary nucleus from the PA that was previously suggested by Krettek and Price ('78a).
In all of our experiments with PHAL deposits in the PA we also observed a moderate number of fibers coursing through the arcuate nucleus, although they give rise to very few terminal boutons.

Any substantial influence of the PA on the arcuate nucleus, as well as on the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus, appears to be mediated primarily in an indirect way, most obviously through its projections to the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, the medial part of the medial preoptic nucleus, and the ventral premammillary nucleus, all of which are known to project massively to these two components of the periventricular region (Simerly and Swanson, '88; Canteras et al., '92).

From earlier parts of this discussion it should perhaps come as no surprise that all hypothalamic areas receiving a dense input from the PA contain many neurons that concentrate gonadal steroids and express high levels of mRNAs encoding the androgen and/or estrogen receptors (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '74; Simerly et al., '90).

Furthermore, all the major hypothalamic targets of the PA display clear structural sexual dimorphisms (Gorski et al., '80; Bleier et al., '82; Arai, '84; Simerly et al., '84, '85; Akesson and Micevych, '91).
The deeper parts of layer I11 of the COApl (immediately adjacent to the PA) also provide a dense input to the hypothalamus.
In contrast to the PA, however, this projection is mainly directed to the medial zone of the tuberal region and to the ventral premammillary nucleus, with very few endings in the preoptic region.

Based on autoradiographic experiments, Krettek and Price ('78a) suggested the existence of a projection from the posterior cortical nucleus to the ventral premammillary nucleus, and several experiments with fluorogold deposited in this hypothalamic nucleus retrogradely labeled many cells in the posterior cortical nucleus, mainly in a zone just surrounding the borders of the PA (see Canteras et al., '92).

However, neither anterograde nor retrograde tracing studies have previously reported a projection from the posterior cortical nucleus to the medial zone of the hypothalamus at tuberal levels (Krettek and Price, '78a; Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Kita and Oomura, '82; Zaborsky, '82; Ono et al., '85; Fahrbach et al., '89).

The reason for this discrepancy may well be related to the fact that the amygdalo-hippocampal transition area delineated by these authors also encompasses part of what we now regard as the deepest part of the COApl, for reasons to be discussed shortly.

In summary, the PA, as we have defined it, has a very characteristic pattern of efferent pathways that can be distinguished from the outputs both of nearby cells and of more superficial neurons in the posterior cortical nucleus.

Interestingly, the major telencephalic and diencephalic targets of the PA are components of the sexually dimorphic circuit, including the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, the principal nucleus of the BST, the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus, the anteroventral periventricular nucleus of the preoptic region, the medial preoptic nucleus, the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and adjacent parts of the lateral hypothalamic area, and the ventral premammillary nucleus.

In addition, the PA projects to several other parts of the telencephalon, including the dorsal endopiriform nucleus, the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CA1, the nucleus accumbens, and the infralimbic area of the medial prefrontal region.

Finally, considering the remarkable hodological relationships between the PA and the sexually dimorphic circuit, it would be of interest to compare the connectional patterns of this nucleus between male and female animals.

In the present study we have not specifically examined the projections of the PA in female animals, although the results of previous anatomical studies in the medial preoptic nucleus and other sexually dimorphic areas suggest that this circuitry is qualitatively similar in both sexes, whereas quantitative differences within particular terminal fields may be expected (see Simerly and Swanson, '88).
Output of the posterior cortical nucleus
In the preceding section, the output of the PA was discussed and compared with certain projections of the posterior cortical nucleus as a whole, where appropriate.

However, even though our collection of PHAL experiments is not extensive enough to provide a complete account of the efferent projections of the posterior cortical nucleus, it does include enough injections for us to make general statements about possible differences between its medial and lateral subdivisions, as well as between the deeper parts of layer I11 and more superficial regions of the COApl.
Our results indicate that projections from the COApm and superficial parts of the COApl (layer I1 and adjacent regions of layer 111) share several features in common.
Thus, both of these structures appear to provide extensive projections to other parts of the amygdala, as well as to a number of other cortical areas.

Within the amygdala, superficial regions of the COApl and the COApm share heavy bidirectional projections and both provide dense inputs to the same parts of the amygdala ventral to the central and basolateral nuclei, which, remarkably, tend to avoid the deepest sublayer of the MEApd as well as the anteroventral part of the medial nucleus (MEAav).

The hippocampal formation (ventral subiculum, field CAI, and entorhinal area), area TR, piriform area, dorsal and ventral agranular insular areas, and infralimbic area also receive an appreciable input from both subdivisions of the COAp, whereas the posterior agranular insular area as well as the perirhinal area appear to receive a much less dense innervation.

It is noteworthy that, in contrast to the PA and to deeper regions of layer I11 of the COApl, these other areas of the COAp have more widespread projections to other cortical areas, and in this particular case to other regions within the amygdala as well.

As mentioned above, our results clearly indicate that there is also a strong convergence of inputs from the posterolateral and posteromedial parts of the cortical nucleus within the interfascicular and the transverse nuclei of the BST.

In view of the fact that the posteromedial and posterolateral parts of the posterior cortical nucleus receive direct inputs from the accessory and main (lateral) olfactory tracts, respectively, the great overlap in the distribution of efferents from the two subdivisions of the posterior cortical nucleus may well play a critical role in some behaviors that depend on the convergence of olfactory cues from the vomeronasal organ and from the rest of the olfactory mucosa.

For example, it has been shown that removal of the vomeronasal organ alone produces severe deficits in the mating behavior of sexually inexperienced but not sexually experienced male hamsters (Meredith, '86).

Furthermore, lesions confined to parts of the amygdala related to the vomeronasal system produce serious deficits in the mating behavior of male hamsters, even if the animals are sexually experienced (Lehman and Winans, '82).

Taken together, these findings raise the possibility that in experienced male hamsters, olfactory inputs relayed by the main olfactory system may be able to sustain mating behavior through their direct accesses to regions of the amygdala that normally receive direct input from the accessory olfactory system.

In contrast to superficial regions of the COApl, it is important to reiterate that the COApm provides a dense input to the granule cell layer of the accessory olfactory bulb, as well as a heavy projection to the opposite side of the brain.

Projections from the COApm to the accessory olfactory bulb have been described in previous retrograde tracttracing studies, which (in agreement with the present study) also suggest that the COApl does not provide direct inputs to this region (Broadwell and Jacobowitz, '76; De Olmos et al., '78).

Our observations indicate that axons from the COApm projecting through the anterior commissure arise primarily from more superficially located cells, and that they provide a very distinct input to the region exactly contralateral to the injection site, in addition to a number of other terminal fields.
The projection to the contralateral COApm has been described previously with both anterograde and retrograde tract-tracing methods (Krettek and Price, '78b; Ottersen, '82).

The results of the present study also provide clear evidence that projections from deeper regions of COApl layer I11 are quite different from those arising in more superficial regions (layer I1 and adjacent regions of layer 111) of the same area.

Unlike superficial regions of the COApl, deeper regions of layer I11 give rise to fibers that end in the PA, as well as dense projections to the septal region and to parts of the medial zone of the hypothalamus.
However, it should be emphasized that all other regions that appear to be innervated by the deeper cells of layer I11 also receive inputs from cells located more superficially in the COApl.

Thus, neurons throughout the depth of the COApl appear to provide a similar pattern of inputs to the medial nucleus of the amygdala and to the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis, as well to the same cortical areas.

However, it should be noted that, with the possible exception of a dense input to the ventral subiculum and field CAI, the projections from deeper cells of COApl layer I11 to other cortical areas appear to be far less dense than those arising from cells located more superficially in the COApl.

Taken together, our results indicate that the pattern of outputs from the COApl is similar to that for other cortical fields, where more superficial neurons tend to project more densely to other cortical areas (and in this case to other structures within the amygdala), while cells located more deeply tend to project more densely to subcortical regions.

Finally, it is important to point out here that our delineation of the COApl differs from that used by De Olmos et al. ('851, which corresponds largely to the periamygdaloid cortex of Krettex and Price ('78b) and also includes a region that we have identified here as the piriform-amygdaloid area (PAA).
As described above, the COApl and PAA present distinct cytoarchitectonic features as well as clearly distinct outputs.

Thus, our anterograde tracing experiments show that, compared to the COApl, the piriform-amygdaloid area provides a much more dense input to the endopiriform nucleus and agranular insular areas, as well as a much more massive projection to the lateral nucleus of the amygdala.
Borders of the PA and posterior cortical nucleus

The ability to localize so precisely the limits of PHAL injection sites allowed us to refine the subdivision of the caudal amygdala by taking account of both cytoarchitectonic and connectional information.
The parcellation scheme that we finally adopted was based on a synthesis of historical, architectonic, and connectional information referred to throughout earlier parts of the paper.

Despite the fact that this scheme must still be regarded as quite provisional, it seems useful to summarize concisely here some the major issues that have emerged and some of the major problems that remain to be solved.
The major conceptual issue that must be dealt with in any study of the caudal amygdala is the widespread lack of agreement about nomenclature and the boundaries of particular cell groups.

We have come to the conclusion that the posterior cortical nucleus consists of two parts, medial and lateral, which are distinguished most clearly by inputs from the accessory and main (lateral) olfactory tracts, respectively, and that the PA lies deep to the COApl.
These basic assumptions raise two questions that require further comment: what is the boundary between the PA and the COApl, and what is the boundary between deeper parts of the COApl and COApm?

To address the first issue, it should be recalled that all parts of the PA as defined here appear to give rise to a similar pattern of subcortical projections, whereas neurons in adjacent (deep) regions of the COApl give rise to a distinct pattern of inputs to the amygdala, septal region, and hypothalamus.

The boundary between the PA and COApl shown in Figure 2 is thus based primarily on cytoarchitectonic criteria (the relatively homogeneous appearance of the PA), supplemented by information from our PHAL experiments.
The second major issue concerns the basic structure of the posterior cortical nucleus.

We agree with the general view that it is best regarded as a trilaminar component of the olfactory cortex (see Price et al., '87), although beyond this, the precise limits of the two cellular layers is not at all clear.
The only exception is layer I1 of the COApl, which is relatively thick and well defined.

Beyond this, our tentative conclusion is that layer I1 (or at least a recognizable part of layer 11) of the COApm is thin and poorly developed, while layer I11 of the COApm is less cell-dense than layer I11 of the COApl, which can be seen relatively clearly to arch medially over it and thus form the ventral border of the PA.
One final point about layer I11 of the COApl is worth mentioning.
As suggested by our findings, and more clearly visualized in experiments with retrograde tracer injections in the hypothalamus (N.S.
Canteras, R.B.
Simerly, and L.W.

Swanson, unpublished observations), it seems likely that this layer in fact contains at least two sublayers, one (deep, adjacent to the PA) projecting rather heavily to the hypothalamus, and the other (more superficial) projecting only very sparsely to the hypothalamus.
One final question deserves mention; what is the most useful way to view the position of the PA within the amygdala as a whole?
When all of the available evidence is taken into account, we suggest that the PA may be regarded as a component of the deep amygdalar nuclei, as opposed to the corticomedial complex.
There are two major reasons for this.
First, like the lateral, basal, and central nuclei, the PA does not have a molecular layer, and thus does not appear to receive direct olfactory input.

Second, it is clear from Figure 2 that the PA is related topographically to posterior parts of the basomedial and basolateral nuclei, all three lying between deep white matter and more superficial parts of the olfactory cortex.
As such, we suggest that the PA represents the posteromedial tip of the deep nuclear complex of the amygdala, rather than a component of the olfactory corticomedial complex.
This argument cannot be extended to the connectional level until the outputs of the posterior basomedial nucleus are understood in detail.
Comparison of projections from the PA and ventral subiculum
In view of the fact the the PA adjoins the ventral tip of the pyramidal layer of the ventral subiculum, some workers have referred to it as a transitional area between the amygdala and hippocampus.

As discussed above, evidence gathered thus far indicates that the PA may be viewed as a deep nucleus of the amygdala, while the ventral subiculum clearly seems to be a cortical field within the hippocampal formation with well-defined molecular and cellular layers.

The following comparison is based on our reexamination of the outputs of the ventral subiculum with the PHAL method (Canteras and Swanson, '92), as well as on previous anterograde tract-tracing studies (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a; Groenewegen et al., '87; Witter and Groenewegen, '90).

Projections from the ventral subiculum course either obliquely through the angular bundle to innervate the amygdala and adjacent parts of the temporal lobe, or travel through the alveus and fimbria to the precommissural fornix and medial corticohypothalamic tract.

In the temporal pole, the ventral subiculum projects to the entorhinal and piriform areas and area TR, to the dorsal endopiriform nucleus, and to several nuclei within the amygdala, particularly to the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus.

Of all these structures in the temporal pole that receive a substantial input from the ventral subiculum, only the dorsal endopiriform nucleus also appears to receive a substantial projection from the PA.
In addition, it should be recalled that the PA projects densely to the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, which seems to be only sparsely innervated by the ventral subiculum.

Like the PA, the ventral subiculum projects to the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus, to virtually the same regions of the nucleus accumbens, and to the infralimbic area, although by way of the precommissural fornix.
Efferent fibers from the ventral subiculum coursing through the precommissural fornix also provide substantial inputs to the BST and anterior olfactory nucleus.

Remarkably, the pattern of projections from the ventral subiculum to the BST is quite similar to what we have described in the present study for the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala: both regions provide a rather dense input to the transverse and interfascicular nuclei, and clearly tend to avoid the principal nucleus.

In sharp contrast to the PA, most efferent fibers from the ventral subiculum reach the thalamus and hypothalamus by way of the medial corticohypothalamic tract, providing a very distinct pattern of innervation to these regions.

Thus, in the thalamus, the paraventricular nucleus and nucleus reuniens receive a substantial input from the ventral subiculum, whereas the PA appears to provide only a sparse innervation, which extends to rostral zones of the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus.

In the preoptic region, the projection from ventral subiculum is mainly directed toward undifferentiated parts of the medial preotic area as well as toward the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus, while the medial part of this nucleus as well as the anteroventral periventricular nucleus appear to receive a more sparse input.

As pointed out above, the anterior hypothalamic region receives only a very sparse input from the PA, whereas the ventral subiculum provides a rather dense terminal field just dorsal to the suprachiasmatic nucleus; proceeding caudally, this terminal field extends dorsally to fill the subparaventricular zone (of Watts et al., '87) along the medial border of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus and the ventrolateral border of the paraventricular nucleus.

In addition, we have observed in our PHAL experiments that the projection from the ventral subiculum to the tuberal region is directed chiefly to dorsal and medial regions of the cell-sparse shell that surrounds the ventromedial nucleus, as well as to the dorsomedial nucleus, in contrast to the PA, which appears to innervate primarily caudal regions of the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and adjacent parts of the basal lateral hypothalamic area.
In the mammillary region, both the PA and the ventral subiculum provide inputs to the ventral premammillary nucleus and to the cell-poor zone that surrounds the medial mammillary nucleus.
In addition, the ventral subiculum projects substantially to the posterior periventricular nucleus.

In conclusion, although the PA and ventral subiculum may share some common targets (such as the dorsal endopiriform nucleus, ventral lateral septal nucleus, nucleus accumbens, and ventral premammillary nucleus), they present quite distinct patterns of projections.

However, in spite of these differences it is important to bear in mind that the ventral subiculum is more like adjacent parts of the amygdala than the rest of the hippocampal formation, especially when its projections to the septal region and hypothalamus are taken into account.
Functional implications
There appear to be no reports in the literature that deal specifically with the functional role of the PA.

On the other hand, experiments with lesions that very often involved the PA and/or its efferent fibers indicate rather clearly that, as a whole, regions in or near the corticomedial complex of the amygdala participate in the control of salt appetite (Nitabach et al., '89; Schulkin et al., '891, antagonistic behavior (Koolhaas et al., '80; Bolhuis et al., '84; Luiten et al., '85; Vochteloo and Koolhaas, '87), and reproductive behavior (Harris and Sachs, '75; Masco and Carrer, '80; Lehman et al., '80; Fleming et al., '83; Lehman et al., '83; Chateau and Aron, '89).

In view of the neuronal connections established by the PA, as well as clear indications that neurons here are influenced by circulating gonadal and adrenal steroid hormones, we will discuss in this section its possible involvement in the expression of these behaviors.

Recently, Schulkin et al. ('89) have shown that electrolytic damage to the medial region of the amygdala, including the PA and/or the stria terminalis, abolishes aldosteroneinduced salt appetite in the rat.

It is important to note in this context that neurons in the PA express very high levels of the mRNA encoding the mineralocorticoid receptor (Arriza et al., '881, and that the nucleus sends a very dense projection to the anteroventral periventricular nucleus of the preoptic region.

Although the specific role of the latter in controlling salt appetite has not been shown unequivocally, electrolytic lesions in the region surrounding the anteroventral tip of the third ventricle known as the AV3V region (which includes the anterovental periventricular nucleus and other cell groups; see Johnson, '85) interfere with sodium consumption (Chiaraviglio and Perez Guaita, '84).

Furthermore, neuronal cell bodies within the anteroventral periventricular nucleus contain high concentrations of atriopeptin (Standaert et al., '86), a peptide that inhibits salt intake in salt-deprived animals when injected into the third ventricle (Antunes-Rodrigues et al., '861, and appears to be regulated by circulating aldosterone (Geiger et al., '91).

Nitabach et al. ('89) have shown that the daily need-free saline intake of female rats is eliminated or reduced after bilateral electrolytic lesions that involve medial parts of the amygdala (including the PA).

Need-free salt intake, which refers to an overconsumption of salt that is apparently not needed to maintain homeostasis, appears to be greater in females, and may actually reflect a suppressive effect of androgens in the male (see for references, Epstein, '90).

Because neurons in the PA express high levels of both androgen and estrogen receptors (as well as mineralocorticoid receptors), in addition to massive neuronal interconnections with the sexual dimorphic circuit, it is tempting to suggest a role for this nucleus in the control of sexually dimorphic aspects of salt appetite.
Further studies are obviously needed to clarify this important issue.

It appears to be fairly well established that animals with electrolytic lesions in medial parts of the amygdala that very often comprise the PA and/or intraamygdaloid parts of the stria terminalis often display alterations of the aggressive behavior accompanying one kind of learning process or another that is an integral part of the test situation (Koolhaas et al., '80; Bolhuis et al., '84; Luiten et al., '85; Vochteloo and Koolhaas, '87).

Although the specific role of the PA has never been addressed in these studies, it should be pointed out that this nucleus projects densely to several regions that have been implicated in the control of aggressive behavior, including the lateral septal nucleus, medial preoptic nucleus, ventromedial nucleus, and ventral premammillary nucleus (see van den Berg et al., '83; Swanson, '87).

Furthermore, it is known that activation thresholds for such behavior depend on circulating levels of gonadal steroid hormones (Floody and Pfaff, '741, suggesting another link between the PA and the control of aggressive behavior.
Considering the results presented here, it seems obvious that the PA must exert some control over reproductive behavior.

Lesions involving rostral parts of the corticomedial complex of the amygdala appear to decrease the frequency of lordotic responses in females (Masco and Carrer, '80) as well as to impair mating behavior in males (Lehman et al., '80).

The possible role of more medial regions of the amygdala in the control of mating behavior has been more extensively investigated in the male hamster, in which lesions centered in rostral parts of the medial nucleus appear to compromise male mating behavior; furthermore, since knifecuts of the stria terminalis may only interfere with temporal patterning of the copulatory sequence, it has been suggested that the ansa peduncularis may be an important route by which the medial nucleus of the amygdala influences this behavior (Lehman et al., '80, '83; Lehman and Winans, '82, '83).

Considering the fact that lesions of the stria terminalis seem to modify the expression of copulatory behavior, further studies are needed to determine whether the PA plays a specific role in the control of this behavior.

Fleming et al. ('83) have shown that lesions centered in the corticomedial complex of the amygdala facilitate the expression of maternal behavior in rats, and that this effect seems to be mediated through the medial preoptic area.

It is known that the medial preoptic area plays a critical role in both maternal behavior and masculine sexual behavior, and there is evidence to suggest that within this region, more rostral parts are preferentially involved in the control of maternal behavior whereas caudal parts are preferentially related to mounting behavior (Gray and Brooks, '84).

It may be important to point out in this context that the PA gives rise to a particularly dense projection to rostral parts of the medial preoptic area (Simerly and Swanson, '861, suggesting that this amygdaloid nucleus plays an as yet unknown role in the control of maternal behavior.
The expression of any behavior involves the elaboration of complex sequences of relatively stereotyped movements and postures that require a great deal of somatomotor integration.

In view of this, it is important to point out that the PA has direct inputs to the nucleus accumbens, which has been proposed to mediate locomotor aspects of certain goal-directed behaviors (for reviews see Swanson and Mogenson, '81; Mogenson et al., '83, '89; Mogenson, '87).

Moreover, it is possible that the PA influences the general arousal level of the animal by way of its projection to the lateral septal nucleus, which is known to innervate densely the lateral zone of the hypothalamus, which in turn seems to Play a role in attentional and arousal mechanisms (for reviews see Kohler et al., '84; Swanson, '87).

One of the most interesting findings of the present study is the pattern of projections from the PA to medial parts of the hypothalamus, which strongly suggests that the PA must play an important role in controlling the output of the neuroendocrine system.

Cells that project to the neurohemal zone of the median eminence and contain factors controlling the release of hormones from the anterior pituitary gland are localized to specific regions in and around the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, particularly in the arcuate nucleus and in parvicellular regions of the paraventricular nucleus (see Swanson, '87).

Because the latter two regions are only sparsely innervated by the PA, the influence of this amygdaloid nucleus on these periventricular regions appears to be mainly indirect, most probably by way of its projections to the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, the medial part of the medial preoptic nucleus, and the ventral premammillary nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, '88; Canteras et al., '92).

The first two cell groups project heavily to the medial parvicellular part of the paraventricular nucleus, which contains neurons that synthesize corticotropin-releasing hormone (Swanson, '87) or thyrotropin-releasing hormone (Lechan and Jackson, '82).

And all three hypothalamic regions may also influence the secretion of prolactin and growth hormone by way of their dense projections to the arcuate nucleus, where the majority of neurosecretory cells synthesizing dopamine (Bjorklund and Lindvall, '84) or growth hormone-releasing hormone (Sawchenko et al., '85) are found.
All three hypothalamic targets of the PA also project to the region of the anterior periventricular nucleus that contains neurosecretory somatostatin cells (see Swanson, '87).

The secretion of luteinizing hormone and folliclestimulating hormone may also be influenced significantly by the anteroventral periventricular nucleus (Wiegand and Terasawa, '82) and the ventral premammillary nucleus (Beltramino and Taleisnik, '85).

Finally, it also seems possible that the medial preoptic nucleus and the anteroventral periventricular nucleus influence the output of the magnocellular neurosecretory system (see Simerly and Swanson, '88).
